tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Vermont actually has the lowest amount of estimated lead service lines!
Correct! Conneticut has an estimated 146,600 lead service lines still in ground today.
Not quite, Massachusetts has the second highest estimated number of lead service lines.

params.question: Concept Check: Which state has the highest estimated number of lead service lines?

behaviour.feedbackOnCorrect: Knowing the exact location of lead service lines, is often difficult in older cities and states, with dated records and aged water infrastructure systems (numerous repairs etc.) This may lead to an underestimated amount of lead service lines reported.
behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: Age of a state or city also impacts the history of records and reporting, a vital source of information for estimates such as these.

params.question: The age of a city or state does not play a role in the estimated number of lead service lines given.

behaviour.feedbackOnCorrect: Lead service lines on public property more often than not, represent the larger number of lead service lines in an areas estimated distribution. Those on private property are often not reported unless known by the homeowner through a disruption of service (i.e a leak) or other reasons for replacement. This may also lead to an underestimated number of lead service lines reported.
behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: Public property is more likely to have records under ownership of the government or other municipalities. Private property reporting is completely subject to the homeowner.

params.question: Lead services lines reported are more likely to be those on private property than public property.
